cmCourseInfo.description: Keyboard skills, corresponding with materials studied in TMU130H1, including scales, chords, harmonization of melodies and score reading. Emphasis on continuo realization. One hour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Keyboard Harmony

cmCourseInfo.description: Performance of pieces (equivalent to RCM Grade 3); scales, chords and cadences in major and minor keys; harmonization of simple melodies utilizing a variety of accompaniments and style; sight reading of melodies, chorales, and simple two-part pieces. One hour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Keyboard Skills
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: TMU105Y1.  Incoming students whose major instrument is not keyboard  may be granted exemption by passing a test during the first week of classes or showing proof of RCM Grade 3 Piano.  Students obtaining advanced standing in TMU107Y1 may enrol in TMU105Y1.

cmCourseInfo.description: Compositional projects developed in consultation with the instructor. For students with direct-entry into the composition major in year one.
cmCourseInfo.title: Composition

cmCourseInfo.description: Survey of digital music technology, covering engraving, MIDI, sound and digital audio, sequencing, synthesis, recording and sampling, signal processing, and mixing and mastering. Throughout this course will be an overview of the supporting hardware and software ecosystem, and an emphasis on listening and analyzing a diverse cross-section of electronic music. Coursework is practical, with a focus on creative and proficient use of a digital audio workstation, culminating in a final project.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Computer Applications in Music

cmCourseInfo.description: Material to be covered includes notation and preparation of scores and parts; introduction to linear writing in instrumental and vocal textures; motives and their extensions; short, strict forms for 2-3 instruments, based on traditional and contemporary models. Primarily for students with an interest in composition.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Composition I

cmCourseInfo.description: An extension of the material taught in TMU112H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Composition II

cmCourseInfo.description: Reading and listening skills for diatonic and chromatic materials. Topics include sight singing, rhythm reading, keyboard harmony, and dictation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Musical Skills I & II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RCM Level 8 Theory, RCM Level 9 Harmony, RCM Grade 8 level performing audition, and permission of Department.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: This course is offered simultaneously with TMU132H1 (F) and TMU133H1 (S) at the Faculty of Music.

cmCourseInfo.description: Diatonic harmony. Principles of voice leading and harmonic progression. Introduction to musical form.
cmCourseInfo.title: Music Theory I

cmCourseInfo.description: Chromatic harmony. Topics include modulation, mixture, Neapolitan and augmented sixths.
cmCourseInfo.title: Music Theory II

cmCourseInfo.description: Reading and listening skills for diatonic materials. Topics include sight singing, rhythm reading, keyboard harmony, and dictation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Musical Skills I

cmCourseInfo.description: Reading and listening skills for chromatic materials. Topics include sight singing, rhythm reading, keyboard harmony, and dictation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Musical Skills II

cmCourseInfo.description: Diatonic harmony, including principles of voice leading and harmonic progression. Chromatic harmony, including modulation, mixture, Neapolitan and augmented sixths. Course requirements include part-writing, analysis, and keyboard harmony/skills.
cmCourseInfo.title: Music Theory I & II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RCM Level 8 Theory, RCM Level 9 Harmony, RCM Grade 8 level performing audition and permission of Department.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: This course is offered simultaneously with TMU130H1 (F), TMU131H1 (S) and TMU105Y/107Y1 at the Faculty of Music.

cmCourseInfo.description: Short pieces in modern idioms with a focus on chamber music or equivalent (e.g. small-scale electroacoustic projects). Public performance of composition expected. One hour of individual instruction per week. For students admitted to Composition as a major concentration.
cmCourseInfo.title: Composition
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: TMU130H1, TMU131H1, TMU132H1, TMU133H1, TMU105Y1/TMU107Y1, TMU112H1 and TMU113H1. Admission by Interview.

cmCourseInfo.description: Short pieces in modern idioms with a focus on chamber music or equivalent (e.g. small-scale electroacoustic projects). A mixture of two-hour group classes and individual instruction. For students admitted to Composition as a minor concentration.
cmCourseInfo.title: Composition
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: TMU130H1, TMU131H1, TMU132H1, TMU133H1, TMU105Y1/TMU107Y1, TMU112H1 and TMU113H1. Admission by interview.

cmCourseInfo.description: Form & Analysis. Study of forms and analysis of repertoire from c. 1700-c. 1900. Forms to be studied include binary, ternary, sonata, rondo, variation, and fugue.
cmCourseInfo.title: Music Theory III

cmCourseInfo.description: Post-tonal theory and analysis. Study of compositional practices in music written after 1900.
cmCourseInfo.title: Music Theory IV

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced reading and listening skills suitable for understanding post-tonal music. Topics include modes, sets, and innovations in rhythm and meter, practiced through exercises in sight singing, rhythm, dictation, keyboard, and aural analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Musical Skills III

cmCourseInfo.description: The first semester focuses on the study of forms and analysis of repertoire from c.1700-c.1900; forms to be studied include binary, ternary, sonata, rondo, variation, and fugue. The second semester focuses on post-tonal theory and analysis of music post-1900 along with reading and listening skills suitable for understanding post-tonal music.
cmCourseInfo.title: Music Theory and Skills III & IV

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth analysis of musical works from c. 1750 to 1840; study of recent analytical approaches to music and meaning, musical form, and text-music relationships; selected readings. Two hours.
cmCourseInfo.title: Analysis I

cmCourseInfo.description: Continuation of TMU210Y1, including extended works for small chamber ensembles. Public performance of composition expected. One hour of individual instruction per week. For students admitted to Composition as a major concentration.
cmCourseInfo.title: Composition
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: TMU230H1, TMU231H1, TMU232H1, TMU105Y1/TMU107Y1, TMU210Y1. For Composition majors only. Part of the course requirement is to have at least one piece performed publicly at the Faculty of Music.

cmCourseInfo.description: Continuation of TMU211Y1, including works for small chamber ensembles. A mixture of two-hour group classes and individual instruction. For students admitted to Composition as a minor concentration.
cmCourseInfo.title: Composition
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: TMU230H1, TMU231H1, TMU232H1, TMU105Y1/TMU107Y1, TMU211Y1. For Composition majors only. Part of the course requirement is to have at least one piece performed publicly at the Faculty of Music.

cmCourseInfo.description: Recording music has become an essential part of a musician’s career. With technological advancements and the ability to reach people worldwide, music has never been more accessible. Through lectures and hands-on tutorials, this course will introduce the student to the basic theory and practical skills required to record music.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Music Recording

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the individual capabilities of standard orchestral instruments. Writing and arranging for small groups - strings, brass, woodwinds and percussion. In-class readings of student assignments. Study of selected scores.
cmCourseInfo.title: Orchestration
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: TMU230H1, TMU231H1, TMU232H1, Composition majors or minors.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: For composition majors and minors only.

cmCourseInfo.description: Practical and analytical study of 18th-century contrapuntal techniques, including species writing, canon and invention. Two hours.
cmCourseInfo.title: Counterpoint I

cmCourseInfo.description: Continuation of TMU316H1 including chorale prelude and fugue. Two hours.
cmCourseInfo.title: Counterpoint II

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of modal counterpoint; strict species technique and 16th-century procedures in vocal writing. Two hours.
cmCourseInfo.title: Counterpoint III
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: If a student plans to study all counterpoint courses, it is recommended to take TMU318H1 first

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the theory of pitch-class sets and set relations, including an examination of referential collections (scales) and their properties and a study of ordered set relation (serial procedures). Readings from Babbitt, Forte, Perle, Straus and others, and analysis of representative 20th-century compositions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Theory and Analysis of Serial and Atonal Music

courses.name: Extended Tonal Tech. in 20th Century Music

cmCourseInfo.description: An analytical study of the music of Debussy, Bartok, Stravinsky and others. The course will focus on harmony (modes, scales, chords), rhythm, form, and methods of motivic and thematic development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Extended Tonal Techniques in 20th Century Music

cmCourseInfo.description: Max is a visual programming language for music and media with an emphasis on interactivity. This course will cover the Max language and environment, MIDI, external and programmatic control, sequencing, synthesis, sampling, spatialization, signal processing, granulation, and analysis. Coursework is practical, with a focus on designing and implementing software for live performance, culminating in a final project. Previous computer programming experience is not required.
cmCourseInfo.title: MAX/MSP

cmCourseInfo.description: The course focuses on song as the pre-eminent form of 20th Century musical expression in several different genres and musical traditions. Students are exposed to a range of techniques for composing songs in a variety of genres and styles: the parallel and reciprocal relationship and development of textual and sonic materials; writing for the amplified voice; prosody and intelligibility of the text in a song setting; addressing a target audience; genre and stylistic convergence in the Internet Age, etc. Traditional song writing formulas and other musical structures are examined under the light of psychoacoustic perception and auditory function of the brain and strategies of how art-music composers can apply their advanced compositional skills to achieve similar psychoacoustic results with more unconventional means will be discussed and developed throughout the course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Songwriting

cmCourseInfo.description: Continuation of TMU310Y1, including writing for orchestra. At least two compositions to be prepared for student performance. One hour.
cmCourseInfo.title: Composition

cmCourseInfo.description: Working in music and sound for video games means not only composing music or designing sounds but building and maintaining complex interactive systems that take players' input and translate it into sonic feedback. This course provides students with the opportunity to create their own interactive music and sound systems for video games, acquiring the relevant technical skills and the experience of team-based video game development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Interactive Music & Sound for Video Games

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will examine in detail the use of percussion in contemporary music and what constitutes idiomatic writing for a vast array of lesser-known percussion instruments. Enrolment is open to graduate and upper-year undergraduate composers and to graduate and upper-year undergraduate percussionists who have some composing experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Composing for Percussion

cmCourseInfo.description: Composing for film will concentrate on technical and aesthetic aspects of writing music for film. Various approaches to film music by well known practitioners in the field. Projects will include creating original music for new films by film students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Composing For Film

cmCourseInfo.description: Available to students in 4th year who have maintained first-class standing in their first three years of study.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Study

cmCourseInfo.description: Available to students in 4th year who have maintained first-class standing in their first three years of study.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Study
